svg.text: Quaylyn's Law Proof - Complete Code Flow
1. Build header strings (search sizes, info levels, N-sections)
5. TRIPLE NESTED LOOP → for each (space_size, info_level, n_sections)
Controls search space size for each test
Controls how noisy/incomplete the information is
for test in range(250): // Tests per configuration
One guess. If wrong, test fails.
• Pick the one with highest score
Get stats from certainty_results[(space, info, n)]
Get stats from nsection_results[(space, info, n)]
• Print comparison table: Certainty vs N=2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9 for each search space
• Show elimination rate and improvement percentage
2. For each search space (5 summary tables):
• Matrix: Info levels (rows) × N-sections (columns) = Success rate %
3. Final proof complete message with key findings
When information is incomplete, directional elimination succeeds
• At 0.00001% information: Certainty achieves only 20-45% success
• Optimal elimination rate: ~33% per round (Trisection, N=3)
• Validated across 80,000 tests, 5 search spaces, 8 info levels

g.text: → Main orchestrator, triple nested loop, 80K tests
→ Returns score with noise based on info level
